case_name: Societe De Traction Et DElectricite Societe Anonyme v. Kamani Engineering Corporation Ltd

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 196 of 1963 is before the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 196 of 1963.

facts.text: Appeal is from the judgment and decree dated November 15/16, 1962 of the Bombay High Court in Appeal No. 32 of 1962.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated November, 15/16, 1962, of the Bombay High Court in Appeal No. 32 of 1962.

facts.text: Judgment of the Court delivered on April 18, 1963 by SHAH J.

anchor.surface_text: 1963. April 18. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by SHAH J.

facts.text: Societe De Traction Et DElectricite Societe Anonyme (Traction) is a corporation incorporated under the laws of Belgium and carries on business as consulting and construction engineers at Brussels.

anchor.surface_text: Societe De Traction Et DElectricite Societe Anonyme--hereinafter called, for the sake of brevity, Traction--is a Corporation incorporated under the laws of Belgium and carries on business as companysulting and companystruction engineers at Brussels.

facts.text: Kamani Engineering Corporation Ltd (Kamani) is a company registered under the Indian Companies Act, 1913.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent Kamani Engineering Corporation Ltd-- hereinafter called Kamani--is a companypany registered under the Indian Companies Act, 1913.

facts.text: On April 22, 1959, Kamani entered into a Collaboration agreement with Traction.

anchor.surface_text: On April 22, 1959 Kamani entered into a Colloboration agreement with Traction whereby the latter undertook to provide to Kamani technical assistance

facts.text: Collaboration agreement provided technical assistance for construction of overhead railway electrification, tramway systems and trolley buses in India, Burma, Ceylon and/or Nepal.

anchor.surface_text: whereby the latter undertook to provide to Kamani technical assistance for the companystruction of overhead railway electrification, tramway systems and trolley buses in India, Burma, Ceylon and or Nepal.

facts.text: Agreement contained arbitration clause in Article X providing all disputes to be settled under Rules of Conciliation and Arbitration of the International Chamber of Commerce.

anchor.surface_text: The agreement companytained an arbitration clause in Articles X, which provided All disputes arising in companynection with this agreement during the period of the agreement or thereafter shall be finally settled under the Rules of Conciliation and Arbitration of the International Chamber of Commerce

facts.text: On September 1, 1961, Kamani instituted suit No. 296 of 1961 in the High Court of Judicature at Bombay on its original side.

anchor.surface_text: On September 1, 1961, Kamani instituted suit No. 296 of 1961 in the High Court of Judicature at Bombay on its original side, inter aria, for--

facts.text: Kamani sought declaration that Traction committed breaches of the Collaboration agreement and agreement terminated, discharging Kamani from obligations.

anchor.surface_text: 1  a decree declaring that Traction had companymitted diverse breaches of the Collaboration agreement and the agreement was on that account terminated by Traction, and Kamani stood discharged from all its obligations thereunder

facts.text: Kamani sought decree for accounts of items in invoice per paras 24 and 25 of plaint.

anchor.surface_text: 2  a decree for accounts of the items companytained in the invoice referred to in paragraphs 24 and 25 of the plaint and for ascertainment of the amount

facts.text: Kamani sought decree directing Traction to pay Rs. 9,00,000/- with 6% interest from suit date.

anchor.surface_text: 3  for a decree directing Traction to pay Its. 9,00,000/- together with interest thereon at the rate of six per cent per annum from the date of the suit

facts.text: On January 22, 1962, Traction took out notice of motion for stay of suit proceedings under s.3 Arbitration Protocol Act 1937, s.34 Arbitration Act 1940, s.151 CPC, inherent powers, or injunction.

anchor.surface_text: On January 22, 1962 Traction took out a numberice of motion for an order staying the proceedings in the suit pursuant to s. 3 of the Arbitration  Protocol and Convention  Act, 1937, and or s. 34 of the Arbitration Act, 1940

facts.text: Kantawalla J. refused the motion for stay.

anchor.surface_text: Kantawalla, J. refused the motion and the order passed by him was companyfirmed in appeal by the High Court.

facts.text: Bombay High Court confirmed refusal of stay and held arbitration clause invalid as contrary to s.389 Indian Companies Act 1956, obliging arbitration not per Arbitration Act 1940.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that the arbitration clause of the companylaboration agreement was invalid, for it obliged Kamani, companytrary to s. 389 of the Indian Companies Act, 1956, to go to arbitration otherwise than in accordance with the Arbitration Act X of 1940.

facts.text: High Court guided by earlier judgment in Societe Italians per Lavori Marittimi v. Hind Constructions Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: In recording that companyclusion the High Court was guided by its earlier judgment in Societe Italians per Lavori Marittimi v. Hind Constructions Ltd.

facts.text: Certificate granted by Bombay High Court for appeal to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: ...in this appeal with certificate granted by the High Court of Bombay against an order refusing a motion for stay of a suit,...

facts.text: Kamani is a company for purposes of Indian Companies Act 1956 by s.3(1).

anchor.surface_text: Kamani is, as already stated, a companypany registered under the Indian Companies Act of 1913 and by s. 3  1  of the Indian Companies, Act 1956,is a Company for the purposes of that act.

issues.text: Whether an agreement to refer a future dispute to arbitration according to the rules of the International Chamber of Commerce between a Company registered under the Indian Companies Act and a foreigner is binding upon the former.

anchor.surface_text: is Whether an agreement to refer a future dispute to arbitration according to the rules of the International Chamber of Commerce between a Company registered under the Indian Companies Act and a foreigner is binding upon the former.

issues.text: Whether s. 389 of the Indian Companies Act, 1956 is an enabling provision and does not compel an Indian Company to agree to refer differences to arbitration only in accordance with the provisions of the Indian Arbitration Act, 1940.

holdings.text: An agreement to refer a future dispute to arbitration according to the rules of the International Chamber of Commerce between a Company registered under the Indian Companies Act and a foreigner is binding upon the former.

anchor.surface_text: is Whether an agreement to refer a future dispute to arbitration according to the rules of the International Chamber of Commerce between a Company registered under the Indian Companies Act and a foreigner is binding upon the former.

holdings.reasoning_summary: ICC rules arbitration recognised under Protocol Act 1937, applicable via s.47 Arbitration Act notwithstanding s.389 Companies Act regulating domestic arbitrations under Arbitration Act 1940.

holdings.text: s. 389 is an enabling provision and does not compel an Indian Company to agree to refer differences to arbitration only in accordance with the provisions of the Indian Arbitration Act, 1940.

anchor.surface_text: s. 389 is an enabling provision and does not compel an Indian Company to agree to refer differences to arbitration only in accordance with the provisions of the Indian Arbitration Act, 1940 i.e. if the Company desires to refer a dispute to arbitration under the Arbitration Act, 1940, it may do so, but the power to submit to arbitration being an

holdings.reasoning_summary: 'May' is permissive; regulates existing incidental power to arbitrate as part of contractual capacity; does not confer new right but affirms and limits exercise under Arbitration Act for domestic cases.

holdings.text: The provisions of the Arbitration Protocol and Convention Act, 1937 apply notwithstanding ss. 3-38 of the Arbitration Act, 1940 and s. 389 of the Companies Act, 1956 by virtue of s. 47 of the Arbitration Act, 1940.

anchor.surface_text: Section 47 of the Arbitration Act, 1940, is as much a part of the Indian Arbitration Act as any other provision and that section makes the provisions of the Arbitration Act applicable to all arbitrations... save in so far as is otherwise provided by any law

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.47 expressly saves other laws; Protocol Act is such a law for foreign/protocol arbitrations; applies to consensual agreements meeting its conditions even if inconsistent with general Arbitration Act scheme.

holdings.text: Arbitration according to the provisions of the Arbitration Protocol and Convention Act 6 of 1937 being recognised by the Arbitration Act an agreement to refer disputes in accordance with the rules of the International Chamber of Commerce is not inconsistent with s. 389 of the Companies Act, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Arbitration according to the provisions of the Arbitration Protocol and Convention Act 6 of 1937 being recognised by the Arbitration Act an agreement to refer disputes in accordance with the rules of the International Chamber of Commerce

holdings.reasoning_summary: Protocol Act overrides via s.47; s.389 regulates but does not prohibit; ICC rules fall under Protocol for international commercial disputes.

holdings.text: Whether having regard to the terms of s. 3 of the Arbitration Protocol and Convention Act, 1937 stay may be granted of the suit commenced by Kamani is a question on which no decision has been recorded by the Trial Judge or by the High Court.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Lower courts decided only on validity; factual issues like operativeness not addressed; remit for determination.

holdings.text: The power to submit to arbitration being an incident of the power to enter into contracts for the purpose of carrying on its business, is unrestricted.

anchor.surface_text: but the power to submit to arbitration being an incident of the power to enter into contracts for the purpose of carrying on its business, is unrestricted,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Company's legal personality includes contractual powers; s.28 Contract Act validates arbitration clauses; s.389 merely regulates, does not limit.

anchor.surface_text: For reasons already set out by us, that assumption cannot be supported. Whether having regard to the terms of s. 3 of the Arbitration Protocol and Convention Act 6 of 1937 stay may be granted of the suit commenced by Kamani is a question on which no decision has been recorded by the Trial Judge nor by the High Court, and we will not be justified in this appeal in entering upon questions of fact for the first time without having the benefit of the view of the High Court on those questions.

outcome.relief_summary: Refusal of stay based on invalidity of arbitration agreement overturned; question of stay under s.3 of Arbitration Protocol and Convention Act, 1937 remitted to High Court as not considered below
directions: Remit case to High Court to decide whether stay of suit should be granted under s.3 of the Arbitration Protocol and Convention Act, 1937
